1 Probability

1

1.1 Definition of Probability

3

The term probability refers to the study of randomness and uncertainty. In any situation in which one of a number of possible outcomes may occur, the discipline of probability provides methods for quantifying the chances, or likeli- hoods, associated with the various outcomes. (Devore p 50)

undefined
5

Given an experiment and a sample space S, the objective of probability is to assign to each event A a number P(A), called the probability of the event A, which will give a precise measure of the chance that A will occur. (Devore p 55)

undefined
7

1.2 Experiment

9

An experiment is any activity or process whose outcome is subject to uncertainty. …

undefined

Thus experiments that may be of interest include tossing a coin once or several times, selecting a card or cards from a deck, weighing a loaf of bread, ascertaining the commuting time from home to work on a particular morning, obtaining blood types from a group of individuals, or measuring the compressive strengths of different steel beams. (Devore p 51)

undefined
11-13

An experiment is any process, real or hypothetical, in which the possible outcomes can be identified ahead of time. (DeGroot p 5)

undefined
15

1.3 Sample Space, S (or Event Space)

17

… the set of all possible outcomes of an experiement. (Devore p 51)

undefined
19

The outcomes in a sample space are noted using the shorthand

21

S={outcome 1, outcome 2, …}

23

For example, if the experiment is tossing a coin twice and counting the number of heads and tails, the three simple events are 1H1T,2T,2H, and the sample space is

25

S= {1H1T, 2T, 2H}

27

If the experiment is tossing a coin twice and writing down the result of the first toss in box 1 and the result of the second toss in box 2,

29

S= {HH, HT, TH, TT}

31

We can define a compound event: A is the outcome of the experiment yielding one tail.

33

1.4 Event

35

An event is any collection (subset) of outcomes contained in the sample space S. An event is simple if it consists of exactly one outcome and compound if it consists of more than one outcome. (Devore p 52)

undefined
37

An event is just a set. (Devore p 53)

undefined
39

An event is a well-defined set of possible outcomes of the experiment. (DeGroot p 5)

undefined
41

Can we also say a sample space is the set of all possible simple events?

43

1.5 Set Operations

45

1.5.1 Compliment

47

“Not A” is represented by four symbols: A′ A  A ¬A

49

The complement of an event A, denoted by A′, is the set of all outcomes in S that are not contained in A. (Devore p 53)

undefined
51

1.5.2 Difference

53

(Rozanov p 14): A−B means the event in which A occurs but not B.

55

1.5.3 Subset

57

(Rozanov p 15): A⊂B means the set A is a subset of B.

59

1.5.4 Union

61

“Or” (union; inclusive or) is typically represented by ∪

63

The union of two events A and B, denoted by A∪B “A or B” is the event consisting of all outcomes that are either in A or in B or in both events (so that the union includes outcomes for which both A and B occur as well as outcomes for which exactly one occurs) – that is, all outcomes in at least one of the events. (Devore p 53)

undefined
65

1.5.5 XOR

67

XOR – “Exclusive or”: A⊕B means the event that is in A or B, but not both.

69

1.5.6 Intersection

71

“And” (intersect) is represented by four symbols: ∩ & , $$

73

The intersection of two events A and B, denoted by A∩B and read “A and B,” is the event consisting of all outcomes that are in both A and B. (Devore p 53)

undefined
75

1.6 Null Event

77

Let ∅ denote the null event (the event consisting of no outcomes whatsoever). When A∩B=∅, A and B are said to be mutually exclusive or disjoint events. (Devore p 54)

undefined
79

1.7 Mutually Exclusive

81

Defined in Null Event definition. Also referred to as “pairwise disjoint”.

83

1.8 Axioms of Probability

85

Devore p 56

87

Often referred to as Kolmogorov’s Axioms

undefined

  1. For any event A, P(A)≥0.

    undefined

  2. P(S)=1

    undefined

  3. If A1​, A2​, … is an infinite collection of disjoint events, then

    undefined

    P(A1​∪A2​....)=P(i=1⋃∞​Ai​)=i=1∑∞​P(Ai​)

    undefined

    Corallary

    undefined

    P(A1​∪A2​....∪Ak​)=i=1∑k​P(Ai​)

    undefined

    Note that many textbooks give the third axiom in terms of a sum over two events instead of a sum over an infinite set of events.

    undefined
undefined
89-101

Devore p 57

103

Axioms do not completely determine an assignment of probabilities to events. The axioms serve only to rule out assignments inconsisten with our intuitve notions of probability.

undefined
105

Corallary to Axiom 3 (Devore p 59 calls this a proposition):

107

For any event A, P(A)≤1

undefined
109

1.9 Geometric Series

111

a+ar+ar2+...=1−ra​

113

In an experiment where the event is either true (with probability 1−p) or false (with probability p) and we run experiments until we get a false, the sample space of all experiments is E1​=F, E2​=TF, E3​=TTF, … and by Axiom 3.

115-116

1=P(E1​)+P(E2​)+P(E3​)+....

118

and we will learn later why P(E1​)=p, P(E2​)=(1−p)p, P(E3​)=(1−p)2p, …

120

This is a geometric series with a=p and r=1−p and thus

122

1=P(E1​)+P(E2​)+P(E3​)+....

124

1.10 Relative Frequency and Interpretation of Proability

126

Devore p 57

128

… most frequently used an most easily understood is based on the notation of relative frequencies.

undefined
130

Repeat experiment n times (each repetition is called a “replication”). If event A occurs n(A) times in n replications, then relative frequency is n(A)/n.

132

Devore p 57

134

The objective interpretation of probability identifies this limiting relative frequency to P(A)

undefined
136

Said another way,

138

P(A)=n→∞lim​nn(A)​

140

If exeriment is not repeatable, prior information must be used to determine P(A) and not everyone may conclude the same P(A); in this case P(A) has a subjective interpretation. See DeGroot 2012 and Ross 2022 for a discussion of interpretations of probability.

142

Python example of Figure 2.2 Devore:

144
import random
1
2
a = [0, 1]
3
4
# Experiment: Randomly select an element from the list a
5
result = random.choice(a)
6
7
# Repeat the experiment n times
8
n = 2
9
results = []
10
for exp in range(1, n+1):
11
  result = random.choice(a)
12
  results.append(result)
13
14
print(f"n = {n} experiments:")
15
print(f"  Results: {results}")
16
print(f"  rf(0) = {results.count(0) / n}")
17
print(f"  rf(1) = {results.count(1) / n}")
18

1.11 Law of Compliments

167

(Devore does not use this, however)

169

For any event A, P(A)+P(A′)=1, from which P(A)=1−P(A′). (Devore p 59)

undefined
171

1.12 Law of Addition

174

(Devore does not use this, however)

176

For any two events A and B that are mutually exclusive,

178

P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)

180

1.13 General Law of Addition

182

(Devore does not use this, however)

184

For any two events A and B,

undefined

P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(A∩B)

undefined
186-188

For any three events A, B, and C,

undefined

P(A∪B∪C)=P(A)+P(B)+P(C)−P(A∩B)−P(A∩C)−P(B∩C)+P(A∩B∩C)

undefined
190-192

Visual proof for two events

194

Imagine overlapping targets A and B and darts are thrown towards target.

196

Viusally, the number of ways A or B occured: n(A∪B)=n(A)+n(B)−n(A and B)

198

Divide by the total number of dots, n, use the relative frequency interpretation of probability, and use ∩ in place of “and”:

200

P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(A∩B)

202

Example

204

If you are in a firing line and two people have guns that shoot a real bullet instead of a blank with probability of 1/3, what is the probability that you get shot (assuming the marksmen never miss?) D draw a tree diagram and a Venn diagram to explain the answer.

206

Answer

208

P(A or B)=1/3+1/3−1/9=5/9

210

or, P(A or B)=(2/3)(2/3)=4/9

212

Check: P(A or B)=1−P(A or B)

214

Example (Devore Chapter 2, problem 12)

216

Consider randomly selecting a student at a certain university, and let A denote the event that the elected individual has a Visa credit card and B be the analogous event for a MasterCard. Suppose that P(A)=0.5, P(B)=0.4, and P(A∩B)=0.25.

218

  1. Compute the probability that the selected individual has at least one of the two types of card (i.e., the probability of the event A∪B).

    220

  2. What is the probability that the selected individual has neither type of card?

    221

  3. Describe, in terms of A and B, the event that the selected student has a Visa card but not a MasterCard, and then compute the probability of this event.

    222
220-222

Answers:

224

  1. P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(A∩B)=0.5+0.4−0.25=0.65

    225

  2. P(A′∩B′)=1−P(A∪B)=0.35 (Based on visual derivation)

    226

  3. P(A∪B′)=P(A)−P(A∩B)=0.5−0.25=0.25 (Based on visual derivation)

    227
225-227

1.14 Product Rule (or Law of Multiplication)

229

(Devore does not name but gives as proposition on p 65)

231

If the first element or object of an ordered pair can be selected in n1​ ways, and for each of these n1​ ways the second element of the pair can be selected in n2​ ways, then the number of pairs is n1​n2​.

undefined
233

235

Use for visually justifying product rule and counting permutations (Devore p 66)

1.16 Tuple

239

A “k–tuple” is an ordered collection of k objects. (Devore p 66)

241

1.17 General Product Rule

243

AKA Product Rule for k-Tuples

245

Devore p 66

247

Suppose a set consists of ordered collections of k elements (k-tuples) and that there are n1​ possible choices for the first element; for each choice of the first element, there are n2​ possible choices of the second element; …; for each possible choice of the first k−1 elements, there are nk​ choices of the kth element. Then there are n1​n2​...nk​ possible k-tuples.

undefined
249

Note that “elements” is used here, but in definition of tuple, objects is used.

251

1.18 Permutation

253

An ordered arrangement of distinct objects, where each arrangement has no duplicate objects. Usually relevant in problems that involve “without replacement”.

255

Suppose you have n distinct objects and you want to put them in boxes labeled 1, 2, …, k. You select one object and put it in the first box. You select a second object from the remaining n−1 objects and put it in box 2, ….

257

The number of ways to do this is denoted Pk,n​ (or n​Pk​) and is

259

Pk,n​=(n−k)!n!​=n⋅(n−1)...⋅(n−k)=n⋅(n−1)⋅(n−2)...⋅(n−k)⋅(n−k−1)...1n⋅(n−1)⋅(n−2)...⋅(n−k)⋅(n−k−1)...1​

261

Do see this, consider

263

6⋅5⋅4=6⋅5⋅4⋅3⋅2⋅16⋅5⋅4⋅3⋅2⋅1​

265

1.19 Combination (un-ordered subset)

267

The number of unique k–tuples if k–tuples with the same elements (but in a different order) are treated as the same. In the team picking example, there are 3 team combinations.

269

Each permutation can be regarded as group of k. If we regard a group as equivalent if they have the same elements, then there are fewer groups than permuations. For example, if the two permutations

271

(1,2)

273

(2,1)

275

are regarded as equivalent, then there is only one group containing the numbers 1 and 2. To determine the number of possible orderings of each permutation, ask how many ways a set of k elements can be arranged. The answer is k!.

277

So, to find the number of combinations, divide the number of permutations by k!.

279

Cn,k​=k!Pn,k​​=k!(n−k)!n!​​=k!(n−k)!n!​

281

Cn,k​ is often called a binomial coefficient and the denoted by (kN​) and referred to as “n choose k”.

283

1.20 Conditional Probability

285

We want to know the probability of event A given event B occured. One way to do this is by counting writing down how we expect the number of times A occured given event B occured in terms of set operations.

287

n(A∣B)=n(A∩B)+n(A′∩B)n(A∩B)​

289-291

The numerator is the number of times A and B occured.

293

The denominator is the number of times B occured - it can occur when A did not did not occur.

295

Note that A∩B + A′∩B are mutually exclusive, so (A∩B)∪(A′∩B)=B, so we can also write

297

n(A∣B)=n(B)n(A∩B)​

299-301

Dividing all terms by n and using the definition of probability in terms of relative frequency gives

303

P(A∣B)=P(B)P(A∩B)​

305-307

We were given that the probability of a student having a Visa is 0.5; the the probability of a student having a MasterCard is 0.4; and the probability that they have both is 0.25.

309

We were asked to find the probability that the student has a Visa but not MasterCard.

311

How is this different from the statement “given the student has a Visa, what is the probability that they do not have a MasterCard?”

313

“The probability that the student has a Visa but not MasterCard” can be written in terms of a conditional probability: P(M′∣V); based on the statement, we know the student has a Visa, so we are given that V is true. We want to find the probability that the student does not have a MasterCard.

315

Using

317

P(A∣B)=P(B)P(A∩B)​

319

we need to compute the right-hand side of

321

P(M′∣V)=P(V)P(M′∩V)​

323

Based on the Venn diagram, we know P(M′∩V)=0.25 and we were given P(V)=0.5, so

325

P(M′∣V)=21​

327

1.21 Bayes’ Rule

329

P(A∣B)=P(A)⋅P(B)P(B∣A)​

331-333

Also called “Bayes’ Law” and “Bayes’ Theorem”. Different forms are also used.

335

https://www.cebm.ox.ac.uk/news/views/the-prosecutors-fallacy

337

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S073567572030543X

339

https://www.mcgrayne.com/disc.htm

341

1.21.1 Simple Derivation

344

Definition of conditional probability for two events:

346

P(A∣B)=P(B)P(A∩B)​

348

Swapping letters gives

350

P(B∣A)=P(A)P(B∩A)​

352

The numerators are identical because A∩B=B∩A. Combining these two equations gives Bayes’ rule.

354

1.21.2 Terminology

356

P(A∣B)=P(B∣A)P(B)P(A)​

358-360

  • Posterior: P(B∣A) (probability after knowing B occured)

    362

  • Prior: P(A) (probability prior to knowing B occured)

    363

  • Marginal probability: P(B) (why “marginal”?)

    364

  • Likelihood: conditional probability on right–hand side, P(B∣A)

    365

  • Odds ratio or relative likelihood: P(A)/P(B)

    366
362-366

Other forms of Bayes include

368

posterior = odds ⋅ prior

370

and the proportionality

372

posterior ∼ liklihood ⋅ prior

374

See also Understanding Bayes Theorem with Ratios, which uses

376

original odds ⋅ evidence adjustment = new odds

378

In medical terminology (see also Wikipedia; notes by ekamperi; and Covid examples: 1 | 2 | 3),

380

  • Sensitivity, Se​ (true positive rate):

    382-383

    P(T+∣D+) = (number of true positives)/(n true positives + n false negatives)

    384

    P(T+∣D+) = (true positives)/(total number with disease)

    386

    where T+ is a positive test result and D+ means “disease present”

    388

  • Specificity, Sp​ (true negative rate):

    390-391

    P(T−∣D−) = (number of true negatives)/(number of true negatives + number of false positives)

    392

    P(T−∣D−) = (number of true negatives)/(total number without disease).

    394

    where T− is a negative test result and D− means “disease present”

    396

  • Likelihood ratio: (See also The likelihood ratio and its graphical representation): LR(r)=P(r∣D+)/P(r∣D−), where r is the test result (could be a continuous variable such as “HDL colesterol”) Then

    398-399

    Post-test odds of D+ = LR(r) ⋅ Pre-test odds of D+

    400

    If r is dichotomous (test result is positive or negative), then

    402

    LR+=P(T+∣D+)/P(T+∣D−)=Se​/(1−Sp​)

    404

    and

    406

    LR−=P(T−∣D+)/P(T−∣D−)=(1−Se​)/Sp

    408
382-408

1.22 Law of Total Probability

506

Let A1​, … , Ak​ be mutually exclusive and exhaustive events. Then for any other event B,

undefined

P(B)=P(B∣A1​)P(A1​)+...+P(B∣Ak​)P(Ak​)

undefined
508-510

Explain this using a table and a Venn diagram.

512

Consider a square partitioned by three non-overlapping rectangles. Draw B as a rectangle inside the square. We can count the number of elements in B using conditional counts:

514

n(B)=n(B∣A1​)+n(B∣A2​)+n(B∣A3​)

516

Using P(B∣A1​)=n(B∣A1​)/n(A1​), etc., we have

518

n(B)=P(B∣A1​)n(A1​)+P(B∣A2​)n(A2​)+n(B∣A3​)n(A3​)

520

Divide both sides by n to arrive at the result.

522

1.23 Multiplication Rule for P(A∩B)

524

P(A∩B)=P(A∣B)P(B)

526

1.24 General Bayes’ Rule

528

When A1​, …, Ak​ are mutually exclusive and exhaustive and P(B)>0, we can write

530

P(Aj​∣B)=P(B∣A1​)P(A1​)+...+P(B∣Ak​)P(Ak​)P(B∣Aj​)P(Aj​)​

532-534

1.26 Counting

540

Three types of problems:

542

  1. Product Rule:

    544-545

    A. Given k ordered boxes and n1​ choices for first box, n2​ for the second, …

    546

    B. Given k ordered boxes and n choices for first box, n for second, …

    548

  2. Permutations: Given one set of length n, how many distinct ordered sets with no duplicates of k elements can be created? (e.g., set = {a, b}, permutations are {a, b}, {b, a}. Similar to a product rule B. problem where n1​=n, n2​=n−1, ….

    550-551

  3. Combinations: Same as 2. except counting all sets with the same elements as equivalent. (e.g., if set = {a, b} only one combination is possible: {a, b}).

    552-553
544-552

1.26.1 Product rule examples

554

One can use a tree diagram, table, or x–y plot to prove.

556

If there are n1​ ways of doing operation 1 and n2​ ways of doing operation 2, then both operations can be performed in n1​n2​ ways.

558

Example

560

Take two steps, each step is North, South, East or West.

562

Put one of N, S, E, W in first box and same for second box. Result is 16 unique step pairs.

564

Tree diagram.

566

Equivalent problem: Sample with replacement from set {N, S, E, W}.

568

Example:

570

If operation 1 is moving north, south, east, or west and operation 2 is moving up or down, then there are 8 possible operations of length 2.

572

Example:

574

Two teams of twelve players each. How many unique handshakes between members of opposing teams?

576

Answer: na​=12, nb​=12, N=12⋅12=144.

578

Demonstrate method computing using loops in Python.

580

Tree diagram

582

Example: Roll a die five times. How many 5-tuples? Create a five boxes. There are six possible “choices” for first box, six possible choices for second box, ….. So there are 65 possible k–tuples.

584

Example: Flip a coin 2 times. There number of 2–tuples is 2⋅2. (Think of two boxes and you put either a H or T in the first box and a H or T in the secon box.)

586

Example: Given three circles of different diameter and four squares of different side length, put a circle in the first box and a square in the second. The number of 2–tuples is 3⋅4.

588

Example: Each clinic has two O doctors and three P doctors and you must select two doctors from the same clinic. How many possible pairs of Os and Ps are there?

590

In the first box, put one of the four Os. For each O, there are 3 Ps to choose from and put in the second box. So n=4⋅3.

592

If each clinic also has three Is and two Gs, how many possible choices for four doctors?

594

In the third box, put one of the three Is; in the fourth box, put one of the three Gs. Then n=4⋅3⋅3⋅2.

596

Example: Suppose you want to pick a team of two tennis players from 3 players, A, B, and C. The number of ways you can pick the team is 3⋅2: AB, AC, BA, BC, CA, and CB.

598

This is not the list possible teams because AB is the same as BA (That is, order is not important.). The list of possible teams is 3, by inspection.

600

2 Statistics

653

2.1 Definitions

655

2.1.1 Population

657

“All” of the data is called the population. A population can be finite or infinite. An example of a finite population is all US citizens. An example of an infinite population are values from a continuous probability density function. (Technically, when you draw a value from a continuous probability distribution, you are actually drawing from a discrete distribution, because there are finite number of values that can be represented as 64–bit floating point numbers.)

659

2.1.2 Statistic

661

Devore p 214

663

A statistic is any quantity whose value can be calculated from sample data. Prior to obtaining data, there is uncertainty as to what value of any particular statistic will result. Therefore, a statistic is a random variable and will be denoted by an uppercase letter; a lowercase letter is used to represent the calculated or observed value of the statistic.

undefined
665

Note that the sample can contain all data, so alternatively, a statistic is a quantity computed based on values in population (the population mean is a statistic).

667

2.1.3 Population statistic

669

A computation based on all values in a population.

671

2.1.4 Sample statistic

673

A computation based on a sample from a population that gives an estimate of the equivalent value that would be obtained if the same computation was performed on the population (see also Devore p214).

675

2.1.5 Random Samples

677

By random samples, we mean a value drawn from a population with a certain probability distribution. In general random samples implies “independent and identically distributed random variables” (often abbreviated iid).

679

2.1.6 Sampling Distribution

681

When we take a sample from a population and compute a statistc, for example the sample mean, we want to know the uncertainty in the statistic. That is, we want to know the probability distribution of the means. That is, if we repeated the experiment many times, what would be the distribution of the sample means for all experiments. The probability distribution of the test statistic is the sampling distribution.

683

If the sampling distribution is known, we use it to compute error bars on a test statistic. Sampling distributions are also needed for hypothesis testing.

685

In HW 2.3, we derived a sampling distribution numerically. It was found that when n values of X were drawn from a Gaussian distribution with mean μ and standard deviation σ and the statistic

687

X=n1​i=1∑n​Xi​

689

was computed 10,000 times, 95% of the time the range

691

[X−1.96n​σ​ , X+1.96n​σ​]

693

included μ. (We say that this range “traps” μ 95% of the time.) We actually did not need to do the numerical experiement when n is large. We know the expected result from the Central Limit Theorem.

695

697-699

The sampling distribution of a test statistic depends on the equation for the test statistic and the population distribution. There are a limited number of test statistic/population distributions for which we know the exact sampling distribution of the test statistic. Simulation can be used in other cases.

701

2.1.7 Sampling Distribution Simulation

703

See sampling_dists.py

705

2.1.7.1 Parametric Simulation

707

Values are drawn from a population with known pdf and pdf parameters and a sample statistic is computed. This process is repeated many times to create a pdf of the sample statistic.

709

This procedure was used in HWs 2.3, 2.4, and 3.3.

711

Example: Draw n values from N(0,1) and compute x. Repeat ns​ and plot the pdf or histogram of the ns​ x values.

713

This method does not have practical value – if you know the distribution and its parameters, you can simply use the analytical equation for the pdf. I generally have students use a parametric simulation to reinforce the idea of the meaning of the sampling distribution of a test statistic – that it is a hypothetical distribution that would result if you could do many repeated experiments.

715

2.1.7.2 Bootstrap

717

The definition of the idiom “bootstrapping”is “get (oneself or something) into or out of a situation using existing resources.”

719

2.1.7.3 Parametric Bootstrap

721

Values are drawn from a population with known pdf and unknown pdf parameters and a sample statistic is computed. The parameters of the population pdf are estimated using the sample. The process is to draw n values from a population and compute a sample statistic. Resample the n values with replacement and compute sample statistic again. Repeat the resampling step nb​ times.

723

For small n, “clustering” can occur because a given value can appear more than once in a bootstrap sample. One way to address this is to add a small random value to each value in the bootstrap sample.

725

Example: Draw n values from N(0,1) and compute x and s. Next, draw n values from N(x,s) and compute x∗ and repeat this process nb​ times.

727

2.1.7.4 Non-parametric bootstrap

729

Values are drawn from a population with unknown pdf (both functional form and its parameters) and a sample statistic is computed.

731

Example: Draw n values from N(0,1) and compute x and s. Next, create a new sample of size n by resampling the n values with replacement and compute x∗; repeat the resampling process nb​ times.

733

This procedure was used in HW 4.2.

2.2 Law of Large Numbers

776

  • Orloff and Bloom, Reading 6b

    778

  • Bulmer, Chapter 6

    779

  • DeGroot, Chapter 6

    780
778-780

The weak law of large numbers Rozanov, p 69: given a δ>0 and ϵ>0, there is an integer n for which the quantity X≡(1/n)(X1​+...+Xn​) (with X iid) will be in a small window centered on μ with a probability greater than 1−δ, that is,

782

μ−ϵ≤X≤μ+ϵ

784

or, equivalently,

786

∣X−μ∣≤ϵ

788

with a probability greater than 1−δ. This means we can choose very small ϵ and δ values and there will always be a value of n for which the constraints are satisfied.

791

The Law of Large Numbers tells us that as n→∞ the sample average defined by

794

X≡n1​i=1∑n​Xi​

796

will be near the population average μ with a given probability. Given n samples from a population, we don’t expect X to exactly match μ. The Law of Large Numbers allows us to make a statement about the difference X−μ. Specifically, the statement involves the probability that ∣X−μ∣ is smaller that a certain value.

798

To answer the following questions, you do not need to understand the Law of Large Numbers. However, if you are interested, more formal definitions and proofs are given in

800

  • Orloff and Bloom, Reading 6b

    802

  • Bulmer, Chapter 6

    803

  • DeGroot, Chapter 6

    804

  • Rozanov, p 69

    805
802-805

2.3 Central Limit Theorem

808

See also Devore p 225.

810

The Law of Large Numbers tells use that if we require X to fall in range that we specify around μ with a probability that we specify, we can find an n value to satisfy our requirement. The central limit theorem says that for large n, X is Gaussian-distributed with mean μ and standard deviation σ/n​.

812

With the Central Limit theorem, we can make statements such as “I took a sample of n values and computed X. If I took many samples and computed many Xs, 95% of the time the range [X−1.96σ/n​,X+1.96σ/n​] would include (“trap”) μ.

814

The Central Limit Theorem says that for large n, X≡n1​∑i=1n​Xi​ is Gaussian-distributed with mean μ and standard deviation σ/n​.

816

Important: this theorem (usually) applies even if the distribution of the values used in computing X are not Gaussian–distributed.

818-819

With the Central Limit theorem, we can make statements such as “I took a sample of n values and computed X. If I took many samples and computed many Xs, 95% of the time the range [X−1.96σ/n​,X+1.96σ/n​] would include (“trap”) μ.

821

Brewer 1985, citing Freund 1962, Mathematical statistics

823

Sometimes the Central Limit Theorem is interpreted in that the distribution of x approaches a normal distribution. This is incorrect, inasmuch as under the conditions of Theorem 7.9 the variance of x approaches 0 as n→∞. On the other hand, Theorem 7.9 justifies approximating the distribution of overlinex with a normal distribution whose mean is μ and whose variance is σ2/n, when n is sufficently large (p. 187).

undefined
825

The above statements are consistent with typical textbook statements such as

827

Rozanov p 79

829

Roughly speaking, the central limit theorem asserts that the distribution of the sum of a large number of independent identically distributed random variables is approximately normal.

undefined
831

Bulmer p 109

833

The real reason for the importance of the normal distribution lies in the central limit theorem which states that the sum of a large number of independent random variables will be approximately normally distributed almost regardless of their individual distributions; any random variable which can be regarded as the sum of a large number of small, independent contributions is thus likely to follow the normal distribution approximately.

undefined
835

However, technically, they are not consistent with the mathematical statement of the CLT, which is

837

DEFINITION. Given a sequence of random variables ξk​, k=1,2,... with finite means ak​=E[ξk​] and variances σk2​=D[ξk​], consider the “normalized sum”

undefined

S∗=D[Sn​]​Sn​−E[Sn​]​

undefined

where

undefined

Sn​=k=1∑n​ξk​

undefined

Then the sequence ξk​, k=1,2,... is said to satisfy the central limit theorem if

undefined

n→∞lim​P(x′<S∗<x′′)=2π​1​∫x′x′′​e−x2/2dx

undefined
839-849

Note that D[Sn​]≡∑k=1n​σk2​

851

Also, Degroot p 361,

853

Central Limit Theorem (Lindeberg and Le’vy). If the random variables X1​, …, Xn​ form a random sample of size n from a given distribution with mean μ and variance σ2 (0<σ2<∞), then for each fixed number x,

undefined

n→∞lim​P(σ/n​Xn​−μ​)=Φ(x)

undefined

where Φ denotes the c.d.f. of the standard normal distribution.

undefined
855-859

Neither forms of the CLT state that for large n, the sampling distribution of Xn​ is Gaussian. It states that if you compute Xn​ many times, the probability that Xn​ is in the range [x′,x′′] will be the same as that for the Gaussian in the limit that n→∞. It suggests that the difference between P(x′<S∗<x′′) and that expected from a Gaussian decreases as n increases, which is why we say, inaccurately, “the sampling distribution of Xn​ is approximately Gaussian for large n”. This statement is inaccurate because “large” and “approximately” is not defined. Also, the CLT not state that the difference ∣∣​P(x′<S∗<x′′)−∫x′x′′​e−x2/2dx∣∣​ is monotonically decreasing for all n.

924

References

926

  • The original Possion paper is in French but is covered in English by Stigler 1982. Possion used limit of Binomial distribution and Stigler notes De Moivre derived a related approximation to the Poisson formula.

    928

  • Derived independently by Bateman using a differential equation approach in Rutherford, Geiger, and Bateman, 1910

    929

  • An simple derivation in lecture notes by D.S.G. Pollock

    930

  • How used in physics lab experiments using Geiger counters: 1, 2, 3

    931
928-931

If

933

  1. in a sufficiently short amount of time, Δt, only 0 or 1 event can occur (two or more simultaneous events are impossible);

    935

  2. the probability of exactly 1 event occurring in Δt is equal to λΔt, where λ is a constant; and

    936

  3. any non-overlapping intervals of length Δt are independent Bernoulli trials,

    937
935-937

the probability of k events occurring in the time interval t=NΔt is

939

P(k)=k!(λt)ke−λt​

941

for sufficiently large N.

943

There were quite a few questions about this problem. It may make more sense to derive it without reference to time and then insert the time dependence at the end.

946

If p is the probability of event in time Δt, and, by definition, λ≡p/Δt, then

948

P(k)=k!(pΔtt​)ke−pΔtt​​

950

Next, using the definition t≡NΔt,

952

P(k)=k!(pN)ke−pN​

954

The interpretation is that if the probability of a success in a trial is p, then the probability of k successes in N trials is P(k).

956

A common use case for this equation is when an event takes a certain amount of time Δt to occur (e.g., a hurricane or large solar flare). In this case, it makes sense to define a rate parameter which is the number events per unit time, which is λ=p/Δt, where p is the probability of an event in Δt. This variable corresponds with how we would describe the probability of an event, e.g., on average 0.01 hurricanes occur per day or in 100 days, 1 hurricane will occur.

958

It also make sense to talk not about the number of “trials”, but rather the number of Δts, where each Δt corresponds to a trial. In this case, we can define a time as t=NΔt. This definition allows us to say “given 0.01 hurricanes occur per day, what is the probability that 2 hurricanes occur in a month”.

960

See also the lecture notes by Orloff and Bloom

In the continuous case, the probability that x is a given value is p(x)dx, which is a differential. As a result, it only makes sense to talk about the probability that x is in a range, e.g.,

P(μ−1.96σ≤x≤μ+1.96σ)=0.95=∫μ−1.96σμ+1.96σ​p(x)dx

To compute a probability density from a histogram, divide the height of each histogram bar by the total number of obervations and the width of each bar. The sum of the resulting bar heights will be unity.

2.5 Expectation values

1048

The general definition of the expectation operator E[⋅] is, for discrete x,

1050

E[X]=all x∑​xP(x)

1052

or, for continuous x,

1054

E[X]=∫x​xp(x)dx

1056

By definition, μ=E[X]. That is μ is the average of X over the population. The variance of a population is defined as

1058

σ2=E[(X−μ)2]

1060

When we invent a statistic (a quantity computed from a sample) that is intended to be used as an estimate of a similar quantity from a population, we want the statistic to be unbiased. That is, the expectation value of the statistic should equal the population value. Two statistics that were considered are the mean and variance.

1062

2.6 Point Estimates

1064

A point estimate of a parameter θ is a single number that can be regarded as a sensible value for θ. A point estimate is obtained by selecting a suitable statistic and computing its value from the given sample data. The selected statistic is called the point estimator of θ. (Devore p 243)

undefined
1066

θ^ is usually a point estimate of a population statistic θ based on a sample of the population. (Why “point”? Probably because we get a single value.)

1068

2.7 Point Estimate Sampling Distribution

2.8 Unbiased Point Estimator

1072

A point estimator θ^ is said to be an unbiased estimator of θ if E[θ^] for every possible value of θ. If θ^ is not unbiased, the difference E[θ^]−θ is called the bias of θ^.

undefined
1074

Examples: If n values drawn from b(n,p) and x are 1, then p^​=x/n is is unbiased estimator of p (Devore p 244, but stated in different way).

1076

If X1, X2, . . . , Xn is a random sample from a distribution with mean μ, then \overline{X} is an unbiased estimator of μ. If in addition the distribution is continuous and symmetric, then X and any trimmed mean are also unbiased estimators of μ. (Devore p 246)

Proof that the point estimator X is an unbiased estimator of μ.

X=n1​i=1∑n​Xi​

The term E[X1​] means the expectation value of all possible first-selected values from the sample. All possible first-selected values from the sample is the same as all possible values of X. Thus, E[X1​]=E[X]. Using the definition, μ=E[X], we have

and

because the x values are fixed and can be treated as constants, we can conclude that E[b]=β.

2.9 Confidence Intervals

1182

Devore p 267

1184

An alternative to reporting a single sensible value for the parameter being estimated is to calcu- late and report an entire interval of plausible values—an interval estimate or confidence interval (CI). A confidence level of 95% implies that 95% of all samples would give an interval that includes m, or whatever other parame- ter is being estimated, and only 5% of all samples would yield an erroneous interval. The most frequently used confidence levels are 95%, 99%, and 90%. The higher the confidence level, the more strongly we believe that the value of the parameter being estimated lies within the interval (an interpretation of any particular confidence level will be given shortly).

undefined

1188

it is tempting to conclude that μ is within this fixed interval with probability .95. … It is therefore incorrect to write the statement P(μ lies in (79.3, 80.7)) = .95.

1190

Another way of rebutting P(μ lies in (CIl​,CIu​))=1−α is to consider two experiments. If experiment a yields a 95% CI of (1,2) and we conclude

1192

The above statements are μ is in range (1,2) with probability 0.95 and μ is in the range (2,3) with probability 0.95. This implies that μ is in the range (1,3) with probability of 0.95+0.95, which is greater than 1. Clearly the interpretation of confidence intervals as P(μ lies in (CIl​,CIu​))=1−α cannot be correct.

2.10 Hypothesis Tests

1232

Devore p 301

1234

The null hypothesis, denoted by H0​, is the claim that is initially assumed to be true (the “prior belief” claim). The alternative hypothesis, denoted by Ha​, is the assertion that is contradictory to H0​.

1236-1238

The null hypothesis will be rejected in favor of the alternative hypothesis only if sample evidence suggests that H0​ is false. If the sample does not strongly contradict H0​, we will continue to believe in the plausibility of the null hypothesis. The two possible conclusions from a hypothesis-testing analysis are then reject H0​ or fail to reject H0​.

1236-1238
1236-1238

Devore p 302

1241

H0​ will generally be stated as an equality claim. If θ denotes the parameter of interest, the null hypothesis will have the form H0​: θ=θ0​, where θ0​ is a specified number called the null value of the parameter (value claimed for θ by the null hypothesis).

1243
1243

Devore p 303

1245

A test procedure is specified by the following:

1247-1251

  1. A test statistic, a function of the sample data on which the decision (reject H0​ or do not reject H0​) is to be based [example x]

    1247-1251

  2. A rejection region, the set of all test statistic values for which H0​ will be rejected

    1247-1251
1247-1251

The null hypothesis will then be rejected if and only if the observed or computed test statistic value falls in the rejection region.

1247-1251
1247-1251

Devore p 304

1254

A type I error consists of rejecting the null hypothesis H0​ when it is true.

1255-1257

A type II error involves not rejecting H0​ when H0​ is false.

1255-1257
1255-1257

https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat200/lesson/6/6.6

1259

The conclusion drawn from a two-tailed confidence interval is usually the same as the conclusion drawn from a two-tailed hypothesis test. In other words, if the the 95% confidence interval contains the hypothesized parameter, then a hypothesis test at the 0.05 level will almost always fail to reject the null hypothesis. If the 95% confidence interval does not contain the hypothesize parameter, then a hypothesis test at the 0.05 level will almost always reject the null hypothesis.

1261
1261

Summary of Algorithm

1263

  1. Choose a population parameter, θ that you want to subject to an equality claim (“null hypothesis”, H0​) of the form θ=θ0​, where θ0​ is the “null value”.

    1281-1295

    For example, suppose we want to test the claim that the mean of a population is 1.0; then θ=μ and θ0​=1.0 and H0​ is μ=1.0.

    1281-1295

  2. Choose an alternative hypothesis, Ha​. For example μ=1.0. The “rejection region” described below depends on the alternative hypothesis.

    1281-1295

  3. Find the equation for θ^, an unbiased estimator of θ.

    1281-1295

    For example if we want to test the claim that μ=1.0, and unbiased estimator of μ is x, so θ^=x.

    1281-1295

  4. Determine the sampling distribution of θ^. This sampling distribution will depend on the population distribution (which is rarely known). In most textbook examples, the exact sampling distribution is known because the population distribution is assumed to be known. Also, textbook sampling distributions for θ^ are usually from a short list of common distributions: N, t, χ2, F.

    1281-1295

    Example: If population is N(μ,σ), the sampling distribution of θ^=x is N(μ,σ/n​)

    1281-1295

    Example: If population is N(μ,σ), the sampling distribution of θ^=s2 is n−1σ2​χn−12​

    1281-1295

  5. Choose a rejection region in the sampling distribution. If the value of θ^ from the sample, θ^sample​, is in this region, the equality claim will be rejected. The rejection region has associated with it an area, α. If Ha​ is θ=θo​, the rejection region is values of θ^ in the the lower α/2 and upper α/2 region of the sampling distribution.

    1281-1282

    Example:

    1283

    If we assume population is N(μ=0,σ=1) and execute an experiment of drawing n values from it and compute xsample​, we reject the null that μ=0 if xsample​ is in the “rare” region of the sampling distribution for x. We do not reject the null hypothesis otherwise.

    1285

    Based on the assumptions about the population distribution and the fact that the sampling distribution of x is N(μ=0,σ=1/n​) if these assumptions are true, we exect ∣xsample​∣>1.96σ/n​ to occur in 5% of hypothetical experiments.

    1287

    Based on this example, when we reject, we are claiming “if we could repeat the experiment many times and compute many xsample​ values, values in my selected rejection region are rare, so I’ll reject the hypothesis if an expeirment yields an xsample​ is in the rejection region; otherwise, I won’t reject the null hypothesis”. Notice that the statements don’t involve claims that H0​ is true or false. They only involve statements about whether the observation is likely or not. In a similar way, a jury’s conclusion of “guilty of murder” is a usually a statement that “not guilty” is unlikely given the information they were presented. The jury rarely has undisputable evidence that the defendent murdered someone; they usually only have information about motive, means, and opportunity.

    1289

    In summary, a hypotheis test has the logic: Given claim + experimental observation, if a given observation is unlikely based what we know about the probability of every possible experimental observation that could occur, reject claim; otherwise, don’t reject claim (it is tempting to say “accept claim”, but that is equivalent to making a statement that the claim is true).

    1291

    See also https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat500/lesson/6a/6a.1

    1293
1265-1293

A confidence interval can be framed as a hypothesis test (See also Bulmer p 169). Consider the test

1295

  • H0​: θ=θo​

    1298-1299

  • Ha​: H0​=θo​

    1298
1297-1298

  1. Test statistic: θ^, which is an unbiased estimate of θ.

    1301-1303

  2. Rejection region: θ^ of sample outside the CI. For a 95% CI, the region is the values of θ^ associated with the left tail of area 0.025 and the right tail area of 0.975

    1301
1300-1301

We can repeat the above hypothesis test for any θ0​ inside the CI. We will not reject H0​ for any θ0​ in the rejection region.

1303

  • H0​: Population parameter θ is inside the CI of θ^sample​ (so θ0​ is any value in the CI).

    1306-1308

  • Ha​: Population parameter θ is outside the CI of θ^sample​.

    1306
1305-1306

Interpretaion

1308

  • “Rejecting H0​” does not mean H0​ is false. It means H0​ is unlikely, where the unlikelyness threshold is determined by the confidence interval width.

    1318-1321

  • Bulmer, p 165

    1318-1321

    The rejection of a hypothesis at the 5% level does not imply that the probability that the hypothesis is false is 95%; it merely implies that the observed result belongs to a class of results whos overall probability of occurrence, if the null hypothesis is true, is 5%. This provides good reason, in the sense of a rational degreee of belief, for supposing the hypothesis to be false, but no numerical value can be placed upon this degree of belief.

    1318-1321
    1318-1321

  • Sawilowsky, 2011, Statistal Fallacies

    1318-1321

    Confidence intervals have recently been promoted over the use of hypothesis tests for a litany of unsupported reasons. (a) Among its supposed benefits is the assertion that confidence intervals provide more confidence than do hypothesis tests. This is based on the fallacy that confidence intervals are based on some system of probability theory other than that of hypothesis tests, when in fact they are the same. (b) Another prevalent misconception is confidence intervals must be symmetric.

    1318-1321
    1318-1321

  • Statistical tests, P values, confidence intervals, and power: a guide to misinterpretations

    1318-1319
1310-1319

2.11 p value

1321

Devore p 328:

1323

Using the rejection region method to test hypotheses entails first selecting a significance level α. Then after computing the value of the test statistic, the null hypothesis H0​ is rejected if the value falls in the rejection region and is otherwise not rejected. We now consider another way of reaching a conclusion in a hypothesis testing analysis. This alternative approach is based on calculation of a certain probability called a P-value. One advantage is that the P-value provides an intuitive measure of the strength of evidence in the data against H0​.

1325
1325

Devore p 329:

1327

The P-value is the probability, calculated assuming that the null hypothesis is true, of obtaining a value of the test statistic at least as contradictory to H0​ as the value calculated from the available sample.

1329
1329

Devore p 329:

1331

Beware: The P-value is not the probability that H0​ is true, nor is it an error probability!

3.1 Linear Regression

1337

See also Devore Chapter 12.

1339

When fitting a straight line to data using the equation y=bx+a, we most often make the following assumptions about the process that generated the data. First, we assume that each of the sampled yi​ (i=1,...,n) values were generated by drawing a value from a Gaussian distribution with μ=0 and standard deviation σ and then adding to it βxi​+α, where xi​ are values that are known with zero uncertainty. The values of α and β are unknown quantities that we seek to estimate given a limited set of n measurements of the population and equations for a and b (involving xi​ and yi​) that you typically first encounter in a physics lab.

1341

To simulate the process of generating yi​ values described above, choose a value for xi​. Next, draw a value from a Gaussian distribution with a mean of zero and standard deviation of σ, the value of which is represented by the variable ϵi​. Then solve for yi​ using

1343

yi​=βxi​+α+ϵi​

1345

Repeating this process n times will yield n values of y and x. When we do linear regression on a set of measurements, we assume that the system we took measurements from works in a way that is equivalent to the above process – we give the system an input of xi​ and it returns an output yi​ based on this process.

In this problem, you will create a population of N values using a linear relationship and then draw a sample of n (x,y) values. Then, you will compute a and b, which are estimates of the respective population parameters α and β.

    1354-1356

3.5 Raw Periodogram

1451

The fourier series model for y having an odd number N time steps is

1453

yt​=α0​+i=1∑q​[αi​cos(2πfi​t)+βi​sin(2πfi​t)]+ϵt​

1455

and has least-squares estimates of α and β (the fact that these are the least-square estimates can be shown) of

1457

a0​=N1​t=1∑N​yt​≡y​ ai​=N2​t=1∑N​yt​cos(2πfi​t) bi​=N2​t=1∑N​yt​sin(2πfi​t)

1459-1463

where fi​≡Ni​

1465

with i=1,2,...,q and q=(N−1)/2, so that there is a total of N unknown parameters in the model equation.

1467

If N is even, then q=N/2 and bq​=0 and the number of free parameters in the model equation is still N. Also, the last a terms simplifies: aq​=N1​t=1∑N​yt​(−1)t.

1469

The equations for the parameter estimates ai​ and bi​ are found by multiplying the fourier series model equation by cos(2πfi​t) and sin(2πfi​t) and then summing both sides over t=1 to N.

The raw periodogram is defined as

1473

I(fi​)=2N​(ai2​+bi2​)

for i=1,2,...,q.

The sampling distribution of I(fi​) is χ22​ (Chi-squared with two degrees of freedom) unless i=0 or i=N/2 when N is even, in which case it is χ12​ (Chi-squared with two degrees of freedom). 3.6 Spectrograms and STFT

1491

Quite often, the periodicities in a signal change with time. For example for the first half a measurement of a time series, there may be a single dominant frequency. In the second half, the dominant frequency may have changed. If one computes the periodogram of the entire time series, there will be peaks at the two dominant frequencies, but the fact that the dominant frequency was time dependent is lost.

1493

A spectrogram is based on a series of “Short–Time Fourier Transforms” (STFTs). The procedure is to split the full time series into segments and compute the Fourier coefficients for each segment.

1495

  1. Create a time series segment of length N=1000 that is a sin wave of period 20. Append to this a time series segment of length N=1000 that is a sin wave with period 10. Plot the combined time series.

    1500-1501

  2. Compute and plot the periodogram of the combined time series.

    1500-1501

  3. Compute and plot the periodogram of each segment. Put the periodograms in a numpy array with two rows. Plot the periodograms on the same axis.

    1500-1501

  4. Compute n=200 periodograms by splitting the full time series (length 2000) into non–overlapping subsegments of length 10. Put the periodograms into a numpy array with 200 rows. Plot the matrix as a heatmap. The x axis should be the subsegment number (1,...,200), the y axis should be frequency, and the colorbar should correspond to I.

    1500
1497-1500
